creator: rshah@aclcargo.com
text:
"I noticed in my Apache log that some bad guys were directing requests thru my 
server - to save themselves bandwidth I guess. For example, they would send 
a "GET http://www.somesite.com/blah/blah.hmtl" request. I disabled this by 
doing: ProxyRequests Off in my Apache http.conf file. But they are still at 
it ..."

People probe for open proxies all the time in an attempt to conceal their  identity.  Just because they made the request doesn't mean it worked.  You  didn't say what the response code in the log was.  For an arbitrary URL,  probably 404 or 403.  For http://www.somesite.com/, probably 200 -- but even  that doesn't mean the proxying actually worked; it probably means Apache served  the request with your own default virtual host.  For further assistance on this matter, please direct your queries to the users' mailing list at http://httpd.apache.org/userslist.html .  Thanks for using Apache!
creator: jwoolley@apache.org
rshah@aclcargo.com
text:
Then how do I see in log like this
"GET http://www.somesite.com/blah/blah.hmtl HTTP/1.1" 200 529 
where www.somesite.com is not my site but is working some other site.


Thanks
Ritesh

What response do you get, when doing the request manually (using netcat or
telnet or something)?
creator: nd@perlig.de
nd@perlig.de
text:
No further response. Assuming issue resolved.

Please reopen the bug if this is not the case and you can provide the requested
information.

Thanks for using Apache.
